tweets.text: "We suspect it will be somewhat surprising to many casual observers to imagine that Charter 'starts' with something like 650-850K broadband net additions 'in the bag' annually, and Comcast 'starts' with something like 500-600K," Moffett wrote. $CHTR $CMCSA https://t.co/egiqUtxkjF

$CMCSA Comcast Corp. - Update on Comcast deck

Members --> https://t.co/7yQEY1bjiG
*no sample available* https://t.co/narLlJfWJL

$CMCSA Comcast update deck is complete, just having issues with Wordpress...Will post it as soon as I can, having issues all day.

Next up?
 - $CHTR update ?
- $NFLX ?

I’m not a fan of how competitive $ATUS footprint has been and will get to over the next few years. Still, there could be an opportunity for shareholders based on (a) business stabilization returning, (b) some growth due to HP edge-outs...    16/n
In late 2020, $ATUS tendered a $3bn share repurchase at $34.21/share. Now, the $3bn could buy the entire public float of ATUS stock. The timing of the share repurchases were very poor.   14/n

Suddenlink is now seeing increased competition & combined with existing competition in the $VZ FiOS overlap, ATUS announced in Q4-21 they are aggressively accelerating their plans to cover 2/3rd of their 9.3m HP in fiber (FTTH). They are on the defensive. $ATUS 10/n

This fierce competition puts continual pressure on total $ATUS subscriber growth given this = 1/3rd of total ATUS HP, as well as ARPU pressure due to the promotions. Broadband revenue growth last Q =  3% versus low-mid teens % 2017-2020. 9/n
The problem with Cablevision (Optimum) is about 60-65% of their footprint overlaps with Verizon FiOS (VZ), or about 3m HP. $ATUS 6/n

Cablevision (Optimum) has ~5.3m HP in the NY area, such as Brooklyn, Long Island, Bronx, The Hamptons, Greenwich CT. At first glance the footprint demographics are appealing: very high density, ~80% of plant is aerial, median income is ~30% higher than U.S. average. $ATUS 5/n

Suddenlink (Acq 2015) operates in Texas, LA, OK, AK, North Carolina, and other small pockets across the U.S. for a total of ~3.7m HP. Only about 20-25% of the footprint overlaps with fiber, and thus Suddenlink has enjoyed low competitive dynamics over the last 5+ years. $ATUS 3/n
Altice U.S. ( $ATUS) was formed through the combination of two cable companies in 2015/2016 – Suddenlink and Cablevision – by then-parent co. Altice Europe N.V. (https://t.co/EKhcIwhkfa). 1/n

Now, at the time I wrote about $GOOG the price was ~ $1,100/share. Seemed "cheap" + strong growth intact, strong competitive position. For $FB, price at time I wrote was $330/share.  - "valuation" was cheap (based on *historical* growth) but future growth less certain....
Relative spend on FB News Feed continues to move elsewhere - specifically FB video feeds, FB instream video, and IG Stories. $FB $MVRS https://t.co/VDZ7pttvm2

$FB massive deck will be out today; a few months ago, FB was a pure play digital advertising business that was gushing cash and had an overly clean balance sheet. Investors were concerned most about FB's "terminal risk". Now, more than ever, I believe it's a bet on Zuckerberg.

What will be interesting on $FB call is any commentary around trends in October (which won't be reflected in Qtr earnings) for users / usage / ad reach / advertiser response given MTD news cycle. Hootsuite showing -3.1% QoQ users in U.S. for Facebook Blue https://t.co/bXVpMEaJGy
